snippet: The job action stems from an attempt by New York City to reform one of the most inefficient transportation systems in the country, which costs almost $7,000 a year for each passenger.
abstract: New York City school bus drivers strike, idling more than half of city's school buses and forcing about 113,000 children to find new ways to school; work stoppage, first of its kind in 34 years, is prompted by fight over union jobs, but its true roots stem from an attempt by city to reform one of country's most inefficient transportation systems, which costs almost $7,000 a year for each passenger.

byline.original: By AL BAKER and MARC SANTORA
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Jenny Anderson, Nate Schweber and Kyle Spencer.

lead_paragraph: The job action stems from an attempt by New York City to reform one of the most inefficient transportation systems in the country, which costs almost $7,000 a year for each passenger.
